For patients coinfected with HIV and HCV, the rate of intolerance to a combination regimen of IFN-α and ribavirin is higher and the rate of sustained virologic response (SVR) lower than in patients infected with HCV alone.
131- 133 Use of peginterferon-α resulted in a higher SVR rate than use of IFN-α.
131, 133 The APRICOT study reported an SVR rate of 40% for patients treated with peginterferon-α plus ribavirin, compared with 20% for those treated with peginterferon-α monotherapy, and 12% for those treated with IFN-α plus ribavirin.
132 A lower SVR rate to combination peginterferon-α plus ribavirin therapy was observed in patients coinfected with HCV genotype 1 (29%) than with HCV genotypes 2 and 3 (62%).
132, 133 Guidelines for the management of HIV and HCV coinfection have been published recently.
130 In general, the guidelines recommend combination therapy with peginterferon-α and ribavirin for 48 weeks.
